content.description: The initial chimney will be easier for shorter climbers who can fit in nicely, but expect to hear groaning.
Make your way up the outer edge of the arete, then up on face edges.
content.location: Left of the challenging "Hard Guy Wall", towards the right end of the main cliff band.  At a right-facing corner.

content.description: Small cracks lead to horizontal seam (crux).  Head right to more cracks that lead to tree.  Tough little traverse.
content.protection: small gear, 3 bolts, fixed anchor.  Micronuts useful for horizontal
content.location: starts on a boulder that drops off on the right. To the right of a dark, fragile-looking flake on the wall to the left.

content.description: Start up a handcrack and move into wider crack that is substantially dirtier as you go.
content.location: next to a boulder and just left of where the cliff turns a corner to become the "Hard Guy" Wall.  Rap from a tree.

content.description:
First pitch starts in a dirty grass-filled crack and leads to a slab section.  Second pitch leaves the top of the slab and around the overhang via a right-facing corner. 

  Rappel using a 60m rope to trees along left side of wall.  Down climb to the base.
content.location: Look for grassy filled crack near the Great Dihedral area.

content.description: No gear here - just a solo up white slab for 200' to the top of Huckleberry Mt.  Nice setting to a great view.
content.location: at the end of the main cliff, right of the "Hard Guy" Wall, there is a dirty, chossy gully that provides access to the forest above the Main Wall.  Spy the white slabby cliff above and make your way over there.  Downclimb the route or make your way through trees/dirt back to the top of the gulley.

content.description: Huckleberry Mountain is directly adjacent to Crane Mountain, making the approach and parking nearly identical.  Most of the routes were developed in the early-mid 1990s.
